name: Black Economic Life: Labor, Business, and Wealth

chapters.name: Slavery as an Economic System
topics: How did enslaved labor generate the wealth that built the American economy — from cotton to finance?
What was the economic value of enslaved people as property, and how were they used as collateral, traded, and insured?
How did Northern banks, insurance companies, and textile mills profit directly from Southern slavery?
What economic argument do historians make when they say slavery was modern capitalism, not a premodern relic?
How much wealth was extracted from enslaved labor over 250 years, and where did it go?
Why is understanding slavery as economics — not just morality — essential for understanding the racial wealth gap?

chapters.name: Sharecropping, Debt Peonage, and Economic Subjugation After Slavery
topics: How did sharecropping replace slavery with a system that kept Black farmers in permanent economic dependency?
What were crop lien laws, and how did they trap sharecroppers in cycles of debt?
How did convict leasing create a system of forced labor that was in some ways worse than slavery?
What happened to the promise of land redistribution — '40 acres and a mule' — and how did its failure shape Black economic life?
How did Black farmers who managed to acquire land face theft through tax sales, fraud, and violence?
What was the long-term economic impact of denying formerly enslaved people access to land and capital?

chapters.name: Black Labor and the American Worker
topics: How were Black workers systematically excluded from skilled trades, unions, and industrial employment?
What was the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, and how did A. Philip Randolph build the first major Black labor union?
How did Black workers serve as strikebreakers — often the only jobs available to them — and how did that create racial tensions?
What role did Black women play in the labor force — as domestic workers, laundresses, and later factory workers?
How did the Great Migration transform Black workers from agricultural laborers into industrial workers?
What was the impact of deindustrialization on Black communities that had built their middle class around factory jobs?

chapters.name: Black Entrepreneurship and Business Districts
topics: What was Black Wall Street in Tulsa, Oklahoma, and how did its destruction in 1921 reveal the violent enforcement of Black economic subordination?
How did Black business districts develop in segregated cities — Durham, Atlanta, Chicago, Harlem?
What role did Black-owned banks, insurance companies, and newspapers play in community economic life?
How did Madam C.J. Walker become the first self-made female millionaire in America through hair care products?
What obstacles did Black entrepreneurs face — lack of access to capital, exclusion from markets, white economic violence?
How did integration both open new opportunities and destroy some Black businesses that had thrived under segregation?

chapters.name: Housing Discrimination and the Racial Wealth Gap
topics: How did federal housing policy — redlining, restrictive covenants, discriminatory lending — systematically exclude Black Americans from homeownership?
What was redlining, and how did the Home Owners' Loan Corporation's maps determine which neighborhoods would receive investment?
How did the GI Bill, which theoretically benefited all veterans, disproportionately exclude Black veterans from its housing and education benefits?
What is the racial wealth gap today — the median Black family has roughly one-tenth the wealth of the median white family — and how was it created?
How did predatory lending target Black homeowners in the lead-up to the 2008 financial crisis?
Why is housing policy the single most important factor in explaining the racial wealth gap?

chapters.name: The Black Middle Class: Growth, Fragility, and Paradox
topics: How did the Black middle class grow dramatically after the Civil Rights Movement and the opening of professional opportunities?
Why is the Black middle class more fragile than the white middle class — with less wealth, more debt, and greater vulnerability to economic shocks?
How do college-educated Black Americans still face a wealth gap compared to white Americans with similar education?
What role do government employment, the military, and HBCUs play in Black middle-class formation?
How does residential segregation affect Black middle-class families — who often live in neighborhoods with fewer resources than white families of similar income?
What does the existence of a Black middle class mean for arguments about systemic racism — does it prove progress or reveal persistent inequality?

chapters.name: Black Poverty, Mass Incarceration, and Economic Exclusion
topics: What are the structural causes of Black poverty — not individual failure but systemic exclusion from wealth-building opportunities?
How does mass incarceration function as an economic system that extracts labor and destroys wealth in Black communities?
What is the economic impact of a criminal record on employment, housing, and civic participation?
How do food deserts, banking deserts, and transportation barriers create economic isolation in Black neighborhoods?
What is the school-to-prison pipeline, and how does it divert Black youth from economic opportunity?
How do payday lending, check cashing, and other predatory financial services extract wealth from Black communities?

chapters.name: Reparations and Economic Justice
topics: What is the economic case for reparations — that the racial wealth gap is the direct result of centuries of theft?
How have reparations proposals been structured — from HR 40 to baby bonds to direct payments?
What do economists estimate as the economic value of unpaid slave labor, stolen land, and denied opportunities?
How have other reparations programs worked — Japanese American internment compensation, German payments to Holocaust survivors?
What is the relationship between reparations and broader economic justice — universal programs versus race-specific ones?
Why has reparations moved from a fringe idea to mainstream political discussion?

chapters.name: Contemporary Black Economics: Tech, Media, and New Wealth
topics: How has Black entrepreneurship evolved in the tech era — from Silicon Valley's diversity problem to Black-founded startups?
What role do Black cultural producers — athletes, musicians, entertainers — play in wealth creation and economic influence?
How has social media enabled new forms of Black economic activity — influencers, direct-to-consumer brands, crowdfunding?
What is the 'buy Black' movement, and what are its economic possibilities and limitations?
How do cryptocurrency, decentralized finance, and other financial innovations intersect with Black economic empowerment?
What would genuine economic equality look like, and what structural changes would be required to achieve it?
